text: Welcome to MothEd. Together over the next few weeks we're going to get to research moths.

Let's begin with our assumptions and prior knowledge about moths. Please create a drawing of a moth, either by choosing the drawing tool (pencil) on the right or by dragging this drawing tile below into your document.
Now create a description of your moth using a text tile (letter A at right).
Have each person quickly introduces themself with their first name (‚ÄúI‚Äôm Amanda or Miss Amanda, and I teach about bugs‚Äù)
We will tell also introduce the camera equipment.
The first task asks students to draw moths. If they ask, ‚ÄúWhat is a moth?‚Äù we can tell them a moth is a type of insect. They should draw what they think a moth might be.
Students should each do their own drawing without looking at other folks‚Äô drawings and without talking.

Divide class into small groups of 4 or less. Make sure each group is in the same Group shown in the top right of the screen. If they aren't, have them click the group number, leave, and join whichever group number they are assigned.
It's important that students record their own and each others exact words, not an interpretation from an adult.
We are here to learn about moths together. What do you know about moths?

Make sure all the members of your group are in the same group number at the top right of your screen. Use the group view and share controls so that you can see and share each others notes with students in your group. Talk with your group about what you know about moths; take notes and make a list in your Field Notes section.
Find some photos of moths online. Save them to your desktop and drag them into your document. Discuss what you see in the images.
Encourage your students to document things they find online and save references to useful web sites.
Moths are important in our ecosystem.

• Moths can be important pollinators -- they help plants/flowers make seeds.
  • Moths can be pests that cause problems
  • Moths are an important part of the foodweb
1. Take a look at the pinned moths your teacher has for you to look at.
Write down a summary of

• what do you notice?
  • What can you observe?
  • How do we know we are looking at moths?
  • What are some things that all the moths have in common?

It is important to know how many kinds of moths live in an area, since different kinds of moths do different things -- how do we tell the different kinds of moths apart? Publish your documents to the class to share your findings.
2. Refine your work by thinking about different types of evidence of Moth types and features

• What did you expect to find that you did not see?
  • What did you see that you didn‚Äôt list in Get Started?
  • What did you observe that isn't makes moths helpful or harmful to the ecosystem?
Is there anything you want to add to your final presentation to the class?
Show students each others documents from the Class Work tab or ask them to look at particular docs in that tab. Discuss the class findings.
Ask closing question for students to consider while we are gone: What is one thing you found interesting today? What is one thing you wonder about?
Our town is part of the US Eastern deciduous forest region. What evidence of that can we observe outside?
Get Started: Divide your team into roles: Recorder; (2-3)Researchers; Presenter
Work with your group to draw and/or make a list of what you expect to find when you go outside to look.
To gather ideas, Researchers might...

• look out the window,
  • look around your classroom/home for books or magazines,
  • find images or take photos.
Your Recorder can record everyone's ideas in their CLUE workspace.

Welcome to CLUE! Clue is short for Collaborative Learning User Environment. This environment is designed to make it easy for groups of up to four students to share their work and learn from each other.
When the class starts an activity, CLUE drops students into groups randomly. If you prefer to assign students to groups, have them switch groups by clicking on the group number at upper right.
Let's go outside! Bring your science notebook to make notes and drawings of what you find.
When you come back inside, add your top three observations to the Field Notes Workspace in CLUE.
If you counted the number of certain items you discovered, create a table to share.

Encourage your students to try making drawings of the leaves and plants they find. See if they can make a table with the kinds of data they take - sizes and types of leaves or trees, counts of different species, etc.
Share to compare notes with your teammates!
1. As your group compares observations, the Presenter can combine everyone's findings on their Share Workspace Section to present or publish to the Class Work.
2. After you have agreed on your summary findings, refine your work by thinking about different types of evidence of Eastern deciduous forests:

• What did you expect to find that you did not see?
  • What did you see that you didn‚Äôt list in Get Started?
  • What did you observe that isn't actually part of a forest ecosystem?
Is there anything you want to add to your final presentation to the class?

3. If you still have more time, discuss and list what you might expect to see looking different four weeks from now. What will cause these changes? Your Recorder can list all your ideas to share with the class.

Encourage your students to work together using the Group View (upper right) and Share switch. They can copy items from each others documents by dragging. Then have them try publishing to the Class Work tab to share their posters.
